head.title: Are We Happy? Let Us Count the Ways

hedline.hl1: Are We Happy? Let Us Count the Ways

abstract.p: Letter from Joel Popkin says 'happiness index' described in May 20 article should be included in Consumer Price Index, since quality of life affects consumers

block.p: ''A Happiness Index With a Long Reach'' (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20) has a profound implication for the Consumer Price Index. If the C.P.I. is to measure changes in the cost of living, as most analysts think it should, it should incorporate some kind of quality-of-life index. Including an index like Marc Miringoff's social health index or William J. Bennett's cultural index, both of which have shown declines in the last quarter century, would make the cost of living go up faster than the C.P.I. alone.

''A Happiness Index With a Long Reach'' (Arts & Ideas pages, May 20) has a profound implication for the Consumer Price Index. If the C.P.I. is to measure changes in the cost of living, as most analysts think it should, it should incorporate some kind of quality-of-life index. Including an index like Marc Miringoff's social health index or William J. Bennett's cultural index, both of which have shown declines in the last quarter century, would make the cost of living go up faster than the C.P.I. alone.
If the C.P.I. is to be an unbiased measure of the cost of living, it must also reflect those aspects of the quality of life that affect consumers.
The writer was in charge of the Consumer Price Index at the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 1969 to 1973.
